rivers.name: Amazon River
rivers.fact: The Amazon River discharges more water than the next seven largest rivers combined, contributing 20% of the world's fresh water entering the oceans.

rivers.name: Nile River
rivers.fact: The Nile is the lifeblood of Egypt, allowing civilization to flourish for thousands of years in an otherwise arid desert region.

rivers.name: Yangtze River
rivers.fact: The Yangtze River is home to the world's largest hydroelectric dam, the Three Gorges Dam, which generates a colossal amount of energy.

rivers.name: Mississippi River
rivers.fact: Mark Twain’s stories immortalized the Mississippi River, making it a symbol of American culture and history.

rivers.name: Yenisei River
rivers.fact: The Yenisei River is the backbone of Siberia, where its frozen waters form treacherous yet essential travel routes during winter.

rivers.name: Congo River
rivers.fact: The Congo River is the deepest river in the world, reaching depths of over 220 meters, enough to submerge a skyscraper!

rivers.name: Mekong River
rivers.fact: The Mekong River sustains over 60 million people, with its annual flooding providing fertile silt for farming in the region.

rivers.name: Ganges River
rivers.fact: The Ganges River is considered sacred in Hinduism, and millions of people make pilgrimages to its banks each year.

rivers.name: Danube River
rivers.fact: Flowing through 10 countries, the Danube has been a critical waterway for trade and transportation in Europe for centuries.

rivers.name: Volga River
rivers.fact: The Volga River is the longest river in Europe and was known as ‘Mother Volga’ in Russian folklore due to its cultural significance.

rivers.name: Indus River
rivers.fact: The Indus River Valley was home to one of the world’s earliest urban civilizations, flourishing over 4,000 years ago.

rivers.name: Rhine River
rivers.fact: The Rhine River forms a natural border between France and Germany and has been the setting of many historical conflicts.

rivers.name: Tigris River
rivers.fact: Along with the Euphrates, the Tigris cradled the Mesopotamian civilization, often referred to as the cradle of civilization.

rivers.name: Euphrates River
rivers.fact: The Euphrates and Tigris rivers together nurtured ancient Mesopotamian empires such as Sumer, Babylon, and Assyria.

rivers.name: Zambezi River
rivers.fact: The Zambezi River is known for its stunning Victoria Falls, one of the largest and most famous waterfalls in the world.

rivers.name: Murray River
rivers.fact: The Murray River is the longest river in Australia and provides crucial water to the country’s agriculture industry.

rivers.name: Seine River
rivers.fact: The Seine River runs through the heart of Paris and has inspired artists like Monet and writers like Victor Hugo.

rivers.name: Yellow River
rivers.fact: The Yellow River is called ‘China’s Sorrow’ because of its frequent flooding, which has caused devastating damage over centuries.

rivers.name: Loire River
rivers.fact: The Loire is known for its breathtaking valley, home to historic castles and vineyards along its banks.

rivers.name: Colorado River
rivers.fact: The Colorado River carved the Grand Canyon, one of the most iconic geological landmarks in the world.

rivers.name: Thames River
rivers.fact: The River Thames has been a major influence on the growth of London, playing a role in trade since Roman times.

rivers.name: Jordan River
rivers.fact: The Jordan River is deeply significant in Christianity, as it is believed to be where Jesus was baptized by John the Baptist.

rivers.name: Lena River
rivers.fact: The Lena River is one of the largest rivers flowing into the Arctic Ocean, known for its remote and pristine surroundings.

rivers.name: Paraná River
rivers.fact: The Paraná River provides power to millions through the Itaipu Dam, one of the largest hydroelectric plants in the world.

rivers.name: Dnieper River
rivers.fact: The Dnieper River is a crucial waterway in Ukraine and has influenced the country's economic development for centuries.

rivers.name: Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta
rivers.fact: The Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta is the largest delta in the world and is crucial to agriculture in the region.

rivers.name: Amur River
rivers.fact: The Amur River forms part of the border between Russia and China and is one of the longest undammed rivers in the world.

rivers.name: Orinoco River
rivers.fact: The Orinoco River is one of the longest in South America, and its basin is home to rare wildlife like the Orinoco crocodile.

rivers.name: Irrawaddy River
rivers.fact: The Irrawaddy River is the most important river in Myanmar, often called 'The Road to Mandalay' after Rudyard Kipling's poem.

items.name: Skittle
items.fact: Skittles were first produced in the 1970s in the United Kingdom and have a distinctive fruity flavor.

items.name: Hot Dog
items.fact: Hot dogs, also known as frankfurters, are named after Frankfurt, Germany, where they originated.

items.name: Foot-Long Hot Dog
items.fact: The foot-long hot dog is a popular American food item, often served at sporting events and barbecues.

items.name: Matchbox Car
items.fact: Matchbox cars were first introduced in 1953 and are known for their detailed miniature models of real vehicles.

items.name: Statue of Liberty
items.fact: The Statue of Liberty was a gift from France to the United States and was dedicated on October 28, 1886.

items.name: Deepest Part of the Ocean (Mariana Trench)
items.fact: The Mariana Trench is the deepest part of the world's oceans and reaches a depth of about 11,000 meters.

items.name: 50-Inch TV (Length of Widescreen TV)
items.fact: A 50-inch TV has become a standard size for large home entertainment screens, offering a cinematic experience.

items.name: Marathon
items.fact: A marathon is a long-distance running event with a standard length of 42.195 kilometers, originating from the ancient Greek marathon run.

items.name: Ham
items.fact: Ham is a type of processed meat that comes from the hind leg of a pig and has been a staple in many cultures for centuries.

items.name: Shortest Mountain (Mount Wycheproof)
items.fact: Mount Wycheproof in Australia is considered the world's shortest mountain, with a length of just 148 meters.

items.name: Dr. Pepper Can
items.fact: A standard Dr. Pepper can holds 355 milliliters of soda and is known for its unique blend of 23 flavors.
